comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: Just looking at her distinctive ears, I gather Elsie was Beatrice Kerr's sister... nla.gov.au/nla.news-article10138736 ...Argus 21/9/1907, p. 13 'BIRTHS: Wild (nee Kerr)...on the 9th August, at 47 Oxford road, Blackpool, England, the wife of Samuel Wild of a son' Per the digitsed newspapers Samuel Wild died in Sydney in September 1940...the Argus death notice refers to him as being 'late m.v. Duntroon'...AWM records indicate he died of illness...the m.v. Duntroon (of the Melbourne S.S. Co) had been requisitioned for service in WW2 and was being used as a troop ship... Sam looks v. similar to this chap www.flickr.com/photos/anmm_thecommons/10470510466/in/phot... however I can't find a Samuel Wild on the AWM WW1 rolls...maybe he was in the reserves rather than the AIF?

comment.author: 33147718@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/51979177@N02] I think the serviceman IS Samuel Wild - well spotted. Wild was in the Merchant Navy in WW2 & not part of enlisted forces, so perhaps he was in the reserves? Scrap that - he DID enlist in WW1, his service number is 80307. He didn't get very far though - enlisted (on my Birthday actually) in late September 1918, and joined on 11th October - only 4 weeks before armistice. As far as I can see he was discharged before leaving the recruitment depot. Hopefully this link to his service record works. (Cheers, Penny)
comment.authorname: Australian National Maritime Museum on The Commons

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/anmm_thecommons] ...good find...this might explain why he didn't make it onto the AWM WW1 nominal roll.
